ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: The course is enjoyable and covers fascinating topics in recent Chinese history. Strengths include the kind, fair, engaging, knowledgeable, and accessible professor (蘇老師) and the relaxed atmosphere; weaknesses include sometimes lecture-like sessions. I would recommend the course to anyone who wants an easygoing course in advanced Chinese.
It's a good class for people who are seeking to keep up with their chinese, but do not want too heavy a workload
definitely, great advanced course that isn't too time consuming that lets you keep up with the language.
Yes, especially if you have some background in Chinese reading, I would definitely recommend this course!

Not as good as Wei Su's first semester, which isn't saying a whole lot. The best part of both courses is the text, but you can pick that up on your own. Overall, not a great course, and if you don't have lots of initiative you probably should just take a semester off Chinese. Or find another course!
It's great because it only meets twice a week.

Chinese 159 is a low-pressure course that helps high-level students maintain their Chinese ability without taking too much of their time. It is not a good move for someone who just wants to improve their speaking. The vocabulary is very useful, however.
